did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Records of the Virginia School for the Deaf and Blind at Hampton, xxxx-xxxx
did.origination: Virginia School for the Deaf and Blind at Hampton

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Privacy protected and confidential information is restricted from public access for 75 years per Code of Virginia 42.1-78. Privacy-protected information has been flagged and/or sealed, but not removed from the collection. Restricted information may include, but is not limited to: attorney-client privileged documents, medical information, and social security numbers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Records of the Virginia School for the Deaf and Blind at Hampton, xxxx-xxxx. Accessions 51684, State government records collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Accession 51684 was transferred by the Virginia School for the Dead and Blind at Staunton, 29 October 2015.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Virginia School for the Deaf and Blind at Hampton was established by an Act of the General Assembly in 1906. The school officially opened September 8, 1909 as the Virginia School for Colored Deaf and Blind Children. After several name changes, the school was renamed the Virginia School for the Deaf and Blind in 1980. In 1977 the General Assembly mandated that the school also serve sensory-impaired children with multiple disabilities, and the school named changed again in 2000 to the Virginia School for the Deaf, Blind and Multi-Disabled to include this recognition. The school operated under the Virginia Dept. of Education and the Virginia Board of Education The campus was situated on approximately 72 acres in the city of Hampton.

William Charles Ritter was instrumental in the establishment of the Virginia School for Colored Deaf and Blind Children. Ritter was born in 1872 in Clarke County, Virginia, and attended the Virginia School for the Deaf and Blind located in Staunton, Virginia, after losing his hearing after contracting scarlet fever. He had deep interest in the education of deaf and blind African American children and in 1898, with the assistance of Del. Harry Rutherfor Houston, efforts began to create a school for these children. In 1906 an act appropriating five thousand dollars to begin work on the school passed in the General Assembly and in 1908, Governor Swanson appointed the first Board of Visitors. Mr. Ritter was selected as the first superintendent and land in Newport News was purchased for the site of the new school.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into the following series:

item.emph: Series I. Correspondence and Subject Files, xxxx-xxxx;

unittitle.emph: Series I. Correspondence and Subject Files,

scopecontent.p: Correspondence and subject files, xxxx-xxxx, are housed in xx boxes and are arranged alphabetically. Includes mostly administrative correspondence and subject files, but also contains correspondence of the Superintentdent of VSDBH. Corresponendence was intermingled when transferred. Records contain correspondence, manuals, memoranda, policies, procedures.

scopecontent.p: Annual Reports, 1991-2002, are housed in 1 box and are arranged chronologically. Annual reports cover education services, student life, finances, operations, health services, strategic plannding and goals, and accomplishments.
Board of Vistitor records, 1970-1984, are housed in 3 boxes and are arranged by type of record. These records includes copies of minutes, agendas, correspondence, and reports.

scopecontent.p: Yearbooks, 1982-2003, are housed in 1 box and arranged chronologically. This is not a complete series and only includes 5 yearbooks: 1982-1983; 1992; 1999-2000; 2000-2001 and 2003. Yearbook, 2003, is in Braille.
